title: Low basis theorem
summary: The low basis theorem is one of several basis theorems in computability theory, each of which showing that, given an infinite subtree of the binary tree 2 < ω {\displaystyle 2^{<\omega }} , it is possible to find an infinite path through the tree with particular computability properties. The low basis theorem, in particular, shows that there must be a path which is low; that is, the Turing jump of the path is Turing equivalent to the halting problem ∅ ′ {\displaystyle \emptyset '} .
